page.title: 02THE WEALD
page.content: The Weald has the last remaining tracts of the great forest of {Anderida.}These forests provided grazing for cattle and timber for building and ships. Felling was particularly heavy when the{iron {industry}reached its peak between 1500 and 1650. The last furnace closed in 1813. Many fellings were restocked but {hammer ponds,}the source of water for the{forges,}still remain as at {Chiddinglye}and{Little Strudgate. Typical steep sided valleys run from north to south. A sandstone ridge lies diagonally across the north east stretching from{Turners Hill}south east to{West Hoathly}and is the watershed of two rivers, the{Medway and the{Ouse.}The aerial view shows farms in clearings much dominated by deciduous woodland.
